title: A Heart of Reverence
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy had a saying, 'The world is full of wonders if you just know where to look, and more importantly, *how* to look.' He wasn't talking about grand spectacles, like Niagara Falls or the Grand Canyon, though he appreciated those too. He meant the sunrise painting the frost on a windowpane, the intricate geometry of a snowflake, or the unwavering loyalty in a dog's eyes. Mr. Abernathy approached everything with a sense of awe, a quiet reverence that transformed the mundane into the magnificent. He treated the worn copy of the Bible on his shelf with the same careful respect he gave to a priceless artifact, because to him, it was.

That reverence stemmed from a deep understanding of God's presence in all things. It wasn't just about formal prayers or Sunday services, though those were important. It was about approaching life with a heart attuned to the divine, recognizing the sacredness in every moment, every interaction, every creation. It was evident in the way he tended his garden, not as a chore, but as a collaboration with the Creator. It was in the gentle way he spoke to children, recognizing the spark of God within each of them.

Reverence isn't about being somber or overly pious. It's about cultivating a deep sense of respect, gratitude, and awe for the things of God. It’s acknowledging the holiness of the ordinary. It's realizing that God is not confined to stained-glass windows or vaulted ceilings, but present in the laughter of a friend, the comfort of a warm meal, and the beauty of a silent snowfall. Practicing reverence transforms our perspective. It shifts our focus from what we lack to what we have, from our anxieties to God's provision. It reminds us that we are part of something much larger than ourselves, connected to a divine tapestry woven with intention and love. It allows us to see the world, and everyone in it, through the lens of grace, recognizing the inherent value and dignity that comes from being created in God's image.

Today, let's strive to cultivate a spirit of reverence in our own lives. Take a moment to truly appreciate the simple blessings around you. Approach your work, your relationships, and your daily tasks with a sense of gratitude and respect. Look for the sacred in the ordinary, and allow your heart to be filled with awe and wonder at the presence of God in all things.
image_description: Close up of a snow-covered branch laden with ice crystals, reflecting the winter sunlight.
insights: Psalm 29:2 instructs us to 'Ascribe to the Lord the glory due his name; worship the Lord in the splendor of holiness.' This verse encapsulates the essence of reverence. It calls us to recognize and honor God's inherent glory and holiness, acknowledging His supreme worthiness of our praise and adoration. Colossians 3:17 further encourages, 'And whatever you do, in word or deed, do everything in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through him,' highlighting that reverence extends beyond formal worship into every aspect of our lives.
prayer: Heavenly Father, open my eyes to see Your presence in all things. Help me to cultivate a spirit of reverence in my heart, that I may approach each day with gratitude, respect, and awe. Teach me to find the sacred in the ordinary and to recognize Your divine hand at work in the world around me. May my life be a reflection of Your glory. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What are some ways you can cultivate a spirit of reverence in your daily life? How can you shift your focus from the mundane to the magnificent, recognizing God's presence in all things? What specific actions can you take this week to approach your work, relationships, and surroundings with greater gratitude and respect?
